revision.text: ==English== {{wikipedia|Yaupon Holly}} ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|en|yapan}}, {{l|en|yopon}}, {{l|en|youpon}}, {{l|en|yupon}} {{qualifier|less common}} * {{l|en|yawpan}}, {{l|en|yaupan}} {{qualifier|largely obsolete}}<!--also supposedly yapoon--> ===Etymology=== From a {{uder|en|chc|-}} word, most likely {{m|chc|yap|yap, yop, yą|tree}}, with the second element being either a diminutive suffix<ref>Frederick Webb Hodge, ''Handbook of American Indians North of Mexico: N-Z'' (1912): The name is from Catawba yopun [yopún], a diminutive of yop, 'tree,' 'shrub.'</ref> or {{m|chc|pą||leaf}} (resulting in the compound {{m|chc|yąpą}}); alternatively, perhaps directly from a longer form of the word for leaf, {{m|chc||'yap'hâ}}.<ref>W. R. Gerard, ''Plant Names of Indian Origin, V.'', in ''Garden and Forest'', volume 9 (1896)</ref> ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|GenAm}} {{IPA|en|/ˈjoʊˌpɑn/|/ˈjuˌpɑn/|/ˈjɔˌpɑn/}} ===Noun=== {{en-noun|~}} # The {{vern|yaupon holly}}, {{taxlink|Ilex vomitoria|species|noshow=1}}, an evergreen holly shrub with white flowers and red or yellow berries, found in the south-eastern United States. #* '''2002''', Connie C. Barlow, ''The Ghosts of Evolution: Nonsensical Fruit, Missing Partners, and Other Ecological Anachronisms'' #*: '''Yaupon''' is evergreen like the American holly and the familiar hollies of Christmas decorations, but the leaves of '''yaupon''' are small and smooth-edged rather than prickly. Easy to chew and blandly tasty, they would not stand out in a tossed salad. # A [[tea]]-like drink, "[[black drink]]", brewed from the leaves of this holly (or, sometimes, {{taxlink|Ilex cassine|species|noshow=1}}). ===See also=== * {{l|en|cassina}} * {{l|en|black drink}} ===References=== <references/> ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=anopuy|Pouyan}} [[Category:English 2-syllable words]] [[Category:en:Hollies]]
